2017.04.01 - 17:12:06
The following are the rules that we have agreed upon.. Periodic re-post of Group Guidelines and ObjectivesğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ Group Guidelines 1. This group is for bringing together of GSB bandhus curious to know more or already know about Dvaita 2. Discussions, Questions and Answers leading to better understanding at all levels is key goal of the group. 3. Please keep pictures and photos to a bare minimum. 4. All other topics which still might concern us in many ways as members of society, but when outside the aforementioned areas are outside the purview of the group. Objectives of this group: 1. Create an opportunity to learn Madhwa Siddhantha, Tattvavada and propagate the same. Activities - Shastra Adhyayana, Pravachana, Workshops, Seminars, Quiz, Awareness Programs, Questionnaires, Handouts, Publications etc. 2. Rebuild & enhance a strong Madhva network in general, youth in particular. Activities - Bhajane, Vayustuti Purascharane, Grama Pradakhisne, Cultural activities, Family get together to understand the needs, aspiration of Group members. 3. Promote eLearning and repository of information related to Tattvavada Contents - Information on religious places,Madhwa/Mata parampare, Achara-Vichara, Dasa Sahitya and many more..

Those of you who are interested to join, can do it using the link below. https://chat.whatsapp.com/3KAyS4KXCdR56v8GJFHVdJ

The following are the rules that we have agreed upon.. Periodic re-post of Group Guidelines and ObjectivesğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ğŸ‘‡ğŸ¼ Group Guidelines 1. This group is for bringing together of GSB bandhus curious to know more or already know about Dvaita 2. Discussions, Questions and Answers leading to better understanding at all levels is key goal of the group. 3. Please keep pictures and photos to a bare minimum. 4. All other topics which still might concern us in many ways as members of society, but when outside the aforementioned areas are outside the purview of the group. Objectives of this group: 1. Create an opportunity to learn Madhwa Siddhantha, Tattvavada and propagate the same. Activities - Shastra Adhyayana, Pravachana, Workshops, Seminars, Quiz, Awareness Programs, Questionnaires, Handouts, Publications etc. 2. Rebuild & enhance a strong Madhva network in general, youth in particular. Activities - Bhajane, Vayustuti Purascharane, Grama Pradakhisne, Cultural activities, Family get together to understand the needs, aspiration of Group members. 3. Promote eLearning and repository of information related to Tattvavada Contents - Information on religious places,Madhwa/Mata parampare, Achara-Vichara, Dasa Sahitya and many more..

Vishnu maam is backbone of GSB Madhva. He has authored snippets called Shri Sudhindra Tirtha lekhani describing literary prowess of Shrimad Sudhindra Tirtha Swamiji from their work Namana which contains various shlokas penned by Sudhindra swamiji. Vishnumam is very active, humble down to earth while it comes to clarifying doubts, he has done a detailed study over the years in tatwavada and is ardent reader and his study in the area fascinates everyone. He is role model for those who want to follow the philosophy of dwaita through dedication and passion

2017.04.01 - 19:20:25
This is a story or a fairy tale I wish to narrate about what happened two weeks back. Our members @919448835656 and @919844365153 had a plan in mind to request honorable trustees of Shri Venkatramana temple Mangalore, on installation of potrait of Shrimad madhwacharyaru in the temple. They came with approach to me as we are always like minded and with grace of Lord Shri Veera Venkatesha I penned a draft letter which was later edited gracefully by vasu n Ullas and they got it proposed in the mahasabha but it's always said we think one step and God has planned 1000 steps when letter was moved the Tantri of temple Shri Narasimha Acharya maam said he already had plans to install the portrait and this letter seconded his thought, this was a big surprise and the proposal moved with applause and the great Ananda Tirtharu is ready to get adorned in premises of Mangalore temple. Let's all pray to lotus feet of Madhwacharya antargata Shri bhoo sameta Shri Veera Venkatesha devaru to bless us on path of tatwavada

The basic of the reality is the difference between any two entities. There are three real ones. Vishnu ,the supreme and independent. The other two are jivas and Jada which are dependent on Supreme. The difference between these three is of five types. This is called pancha bheda

2017.04.01 - 23:18:12
Dwaita BasicsÂ :Nitya Pancharatnas for easy understanding 1. What is dwaita ??Â  Ans : in general dwaita means two or the philosophy of dwaita means there exists two entitiesÂ  1. God the supreme entity of all 2. All other entity living, non living, plants, microbes etc 2. Who founded this philosophy ?? Where was the founder born ?? What is the main tagline of this philosophy?? Ans : the philosophy was founded by Shrimad Madhwacharyaru, he was born at Pajaka near Udupi, the basic tagline of this philosophy isÂ  !! Hari Sarvottama Vayu jeevottama !! 3. What is the base for this philosophy?? Did Acharyaru write his own interpretation ??Â  Ans: the base for the philosophy is eternal vedas Acharyaru wrote the real meaning of vedas no where he has told that he is writing his meaning. The philosophy seeks truth and truth can only be weighed based on vedas. 4. What does Hari Sarvottama Vayu Jeevottama mean ?? Ans: Â  HARI Sarvottama : There is only one Lord in this universe that is Lord Vishnu and all others living non living are under his control he is superior among all, Vayu Jeevottama : means vayu devaru or mukhya prana devaru is superior among all jeevas he is next best thing after Lord and his consort Laxmi. Shri Mukhya prana resides in every entity and since he is top among all jeevas we have to pray God via him that is if u r praying Lord Ganesha it should be mukhya prana antargata Shri HariÂ  5. Why is vayu jeevottama and why is he jeeva ?? Ans : we have to understand that the philosophy of dwaita says all except Lord and his consort ( Vishnu n Laxmi) are jeevas. Don't get surprised jeeva here doesn't mean we humans jeevas are those entity from Brahma to minute microbes which are totally dependent on Shri Hari, jeevas can be devatas, humans, microbes animals etc. there is an hierarchy of jeevas which is called Taratamya or differentiation that follows hierarchy system with Lord n Laxmi at top as Paramatma n his wife then jeevas list start from Brahma saraswati, vayu Bharathi etc. We all need to know is that Paramatma is independent and all others from Brahma to microbes are dependent. Vayu devaru or mukhya prana is Superior among such jeevas and resides in every jeeva Â as chief lieutenant to Lord. He carries orders of Lord and works n makes us work through his prowess.Â

There are no tough, difficult to understand technical words which need a long explanation to understand. The subject treated in this is very basic. It is very important. And what Gopal ji has written are points , which should be never ever forgotten when we discuss our philosophy. It is not just our philosophy but it is vedic philosophy. 2017.04.02 - 07:26:34
From Gopal Pai Mani: . I am taking the questions and supplementing the answers given by Gopal ji. . Dwaita BasicsÂ :Nitya Pancharatnas for easy understanding 1. What is dwaita ??Â  Ans : Dvaita is misunderstood by many as having two separate or multiple categories. Actually dvaita is. Though multiplicity exists , it is under the absolute control of ONE. This ONE, called Supreme Brahman Vishnu is the one who matters. Nothing else, which exists is capable of moving it's little finger on its own , so to say. See Bhagavad-Gita where Sri Krishna has beautifully said this. *dvau imau purushau loke ksharah aksharah eva cha.* Purushah here is not male persons. Puri=body. So purushas are those who are residing in a body. These are of two kinds. .. kshara purusha = Those who have bodies which get destroyed. This means these souls definitely are confined and limited in a body. This body is external to their being. So they are helpless and suffer due to this limitation in body. Second is akshara purusha. akshara=that which is not destroyed. Based on Lord's saying elsewhere in Bhagavad-Gita , this akshara purusha is Lakshmidevi. She alone has a body which is not destroyed which means it is not external. Her body itself is Her natural being , svarupa. Kshara also means suffering. So akshara purusha Lakshmidevi has no suffering. Coming to Sri Krishna who is supreme Brahman, what does He say about Himself? Is He also a purusha of a higher grade? Let us see it next. . . Gopalji's answers :in general dwaita means two or the philosophy of dwaita means there exists two entitiesÂ  1. God the supreme entity of all 2. All other entity living, non living, plants, microbes etc ---------

jst adding sir,kshar purush is soul entangled in wrong beliefs and akshar purush is liberated soul

Sanjaykumar Shenoy (918056280552@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 07:55:03
Uttamah purushattu anayah= After saying that the total of jivarashis there are two types the other one is not a third one just as a separate variety. Carefully see the way Lord lets us know about this third one. He is anyah, uttamah. Meaning separate or different type and someone superior. This means the type itself is different. It is not like separating oranges, apples, pears etc. From the lot. The purusha is not to be construed as one who lives in a body. That is why He is to be understood as *paramatma* . At this time it is sufficient to know that *parama* is not just a superior one but an entirely different kind. *Atma* is the one who is immanent in everyone whose very constitution is jnAna. Which He clarifies next. *yo lokatrayam Avishya* pervading everything in universe. This pervading is the meaning of Atma. (Aatatavat) *bibharti avyayah ishwarah* What is bibharti? He is the reason for the very existence of everything else. He not only makes them exist, He supports them. So though we say Sri Madhwacharya taught dvaita, dualism it is the real oneness. Because apart from Supreme Vishnu everything can exist only if He wishes so. Otherwise they cease to exist. Why *avyayah*? Because even when He is the reason for the very existence of others and supports and also does everything needed in the universe He remains untouched and unchanged. And why *Ishwarah*? Banish the thought that there can be any other who can be the Lord of all or anyone who can control Lord.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 08:19:42
Kshara means that which degenerates. So kshara purusha are all the souls which get a body apart from their very essential being which is called *svarupa* After sAdhana they stop having this repeated body entry and exit and are called muktas. akshara purusha meaning one whose body is never subject to degeneration. She is Lakshmidevi. In this shloka there is no reference to Jada prakRiti

2017.04.02 - 09:45:33
Dwaita BasicsÂ :Nitya Pancharatnas for easy understanding on vedas. 4. What does Hari Sarvottama Vayu Jeevottama mean ?? My inputs on 4th and 5th together . We have seen earlier in the Bhagavad-Gita shloka that Hari is someone who is an entirely different entity. Not even Lakshmidevi can be said to be in that class where Hari fits. The only reason why Lakshmidevi is placed alongside Hari is because Her yogyataa or the svarupa is such that She is the closest to Hari and according to the fitness of Her svarupa, Hari empowers Her to rule over the universe. It is not that Srihari empowers and rests , just looking at the things going on in the universe. Remember the previous verse quoted where Srihari says *yo lokatrayam Avishya bibharti avyayah ishwarah* He Himself enters everything in universe and carries out everything. So what about Lakshmidevi? He enters Her too and makes her do and He Himself does everything. Therefore Lakshmidevi, due to Her extreme closeness to Srihari and being most dear of all and because she is not subject to the bonds of samsara, She is included in the isha class. That is it ! Other sentients, jivas are subjected to the bonds of samsara. But these bonds are not uniform. They are there for namesake only in a class called Ruju jivas. Chaturmukha Brahma with His consort and Mukhyaprana also called vAyu with His consort are in the Ruju class. Vayu has the assigned work of leading all others below Him. He has that fitness and capacity. Accordingly He has the highest knowledge, devotion and capacity among jivas. Next to Lakshmidevi He is most dear to Srihari. As Srihari has empowered Lakshmidevi, so also Srihari empowers Mukhyaprana to carry out the works in the universe under control of Lakshmidevi. And Srihari Himself enters Mukhyaprana and does all the works Himself while Mukhyaprana works. The duties assigned to Mukhyaprana are to lead everyone below Him. As all these are jivas by definition, he is called Jeevottama. Mukhyaprana field of control is vast, almost all universe. He has to do everything in the world. So Sri Madhwacharya says Mukhyaprana vashesarvam sa vishnorvashagassadaa in brahmasutra aNubhashya. à¤®à¥à¤–à¥à¤¯à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾à¤£ à¤µà¤¶à¥‡ à¤¸à¤°à¥à¤µà¤‚ à¤¸ à¤µà¤¿à¤·à¥à¤£à¥‹à¤°à¥à¤µà¤¶à¤—à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¦à¤¾à¥¤ ..... Ans: Â as given by Gopalji HARI Sarvottama : There is only one Lord in this universe that is Lord Vishnu and all others living non living are under his control he is superior among all, Vayu Jeevottama : means vayu devaru or mukhya prana devaru is superior among all jeevas he is next best thing after Lord and his consort Laxmi. Shri Mukhya prana resides in every entity and since he is top among all jeevas we have to pray God via him that is if u r praying Lord Ganesha it should be mukhya prana antargata Shri HariÂ  5. Why is vayu jeevottama and why is he jeeva ?? Ans : we have to understand that the philosophy of dwaita says all except Lord and his consort ( Vishnu n Laxmi) are jeevas. Don't get surprised jeeva here doesn't mean we humans jeevas are those entity from Brahma to minute microbes which are totally dependent on Shri Hari, jeevas can be devatas, humans, microbes animals etc. there is an hierarchy of jeevas which is called Taratamya or differentiation that follows hierarchy system with Lord n Laxmi at top as Paramatma n his wife then jeevas list start from Brahma saraswati, vayu Bharathi etc. We all need to know is that Paramatma is independent and all others from Brahma to microbes are dependent. Vayu devaru or mukhya prana is Superior among such jeevas and resides in every jeeva Â as chief lieutenant to Lord. He carries orders of Lord and works n makes us work through his prowess.Â

919028135977@s.whatsapp.net (919028135977@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 11:26:13
This is where Tattvavaada becomes more important. We have multiple scriptures and we start trying to interpret scriptures in isolation. And then we keep saying our scriptures contradict. In Tattvavaada we can experience scientific categorization, taxanomy and hierarchy of scriptures. We can even realize what is authentic and what is some individuals own interpretation (I am alluding to Pourusgeya and Apourusheya). Only after such scientific analysis do we arrive at an inference and don't jump into sporadic conclusions based on certain word meanings in isolation. This also gets back to where earlier in this group it was said if you are looking at 'scientific' you don't get it. Because general tendency around is to forcefit metaphysics into some unexplainable physics and call it 'scientific'. We can't have such 'scientific' explanation here. We look for an analytics pattern which is organized. I am also a beginner and therefore leave a more detailed explanation to those who know.

What is the difference between Rig-Veda and yajurveda sandhyavandane?
919743026057@s.whatsapp.net (919743026057@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:21:47
Differences are minor While we (rigvedis) do achamana with 24 forms of Lord like Keshava, Narayana etc, Yajurvedis do it with names of Vedas. Rituals like Papapurushavisharjana are not there for Yajurvedis.
Rohith Srinivas (918095726821@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:30:43

2017.04.02 - 18:34:36
The gopi chandana applied on the chest portion while sandhyavandane has got 2 different start points for the followers of 2 GSB mutts. ( Kashi mutt and gokarna mutt ) What is the significance behind it ? Please apologise if the question seems to be irrelevant.
919880733893@s.whatsapp.net (919880733893@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:35:27
Each mutt has a different Naama. This is not restricted to GSB Mutts only. The very purpose of this Naama is to identify oneself with his mutt
Rohith Srinivas (918095726821@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:37:13
@919880241668 ma'am can answer this question
Rohith Srinivas (918095726821@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:37:49
There are 12+2 main namas. These 12 are keshava to damodara rupas in shukla and sankarshana to Krishna on Krishna paksha. The +2 are at the start on the top of head with Vasudeva rupa smarana again at the end of all nama dharanas. The shape is deepakara for all namas except bhujas- venu patra akara, on the middle of the chest lotus bud shape.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:42:08
True. But how does the naama signifies a mutt ?what is the connection between naama and the mutt that we follow ?
919880733893@s.whatsapp.net (919880733893@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:42:40
Now there are some extra namas for some mathas. I have heard that the 8 udupi mathas have 8 different types on the sides of chest.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:44:13
Sir, In gokarn muth SAMPRADAYA why we have to put two lines of Nama instead of deepalankakara Nama in right chest?
919743026057@s.whatsapp.net (919743026057@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:44:31
Coming to Gokarn Partagali Jeevottam math, the sampradAya is one long nama on right side of the chest pointing downward. One small round spot on left side of the chest. These are khadga and gurani.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:46:57
ThanksğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™
919743026057@s.whatsapp.net (919743026057@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:47:40
The connection is that the mutt nama is founded by one of the Yathis of the mutt we follow. Just like the 12 main namas signifies our devotion to Lord, the extra naama signifies our devotion to Guru parampara
Rohith Srinivas (918095726821@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:47:59
Thanks ğŸ™ğŸ¼
919880733893@s.whatsapp.net (919880733893@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:49:27
In between the longer nama on the right side of the chest and lotus shaped chest nama another smaller nama pointing downward. This is srivatsa. Then a small round spot between the tip of lotus bud chest nama and middle neck nama. This is kaustubha.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)

Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:52:11

919880733893@s.whatsapp.net (919880733893@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 18:52:28
There is one more difference in applying gadaa mudra by Gokarn Partagali math. If all others apply gadaa at 5 places, we apply at 6 places . The extra one for gadaa is at the base of the back nama. This is because the smriti followed by Gokarn Partagali math has this single extra mudra compared to the smriti followed by others. This is only a minor difference

What is the purpose or benefit of wearing tread (Janeewara) and Namas in Gopichandana. ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™
919845227048@s.whatsapp.net (919845227048@s.whatsapp.net)

Tejas Kamath (919740584757@s.whatsapp.net)

Tejas Kamath (919740584757@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 22:08:47
Tejas Kamath (919740584757@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 22:08:52
Why should we wear yajnopaveeta? Yajnopaveeta is the sacred thread that represents deeksha to perform vedic rituals. Man belonging to the first three Varnas (brahmana, kshatriya and vaishya) has vedadhikara. He can perform sandhyavandana, gayatri japa, agni karya and the like and can also perform vedadhyayana. The pre-requisite to all this is the formal initiation called upanayana where the boyâ€™s father gives the yajnopaveeta and brahmopadesha to his son initiating him into vedic rites. Nobody is entitled to perform any samskara without having gone through the yajnopaveeta samskara according to Manusmruti. One must undergo yajnopaveeta samskara before the vivaha (wedding) samskara. Similarly, shraddha karma is not valid unless the kartru has first undergone the yajnopaveeta samskara. Even when a person does not wear a yajnopaveeta regularly, priests insist upon it during such rituals. The yajnopaveeta is said to have been created by Sri chaturmukha brahma himself for this very purpose: brahmagre kalpayamasa vedarhanamanuttamam yenamse dhrutamatrena brahmasutrena te dvijah bhavanti brAhmana nama vedarhashcha trayastvih || The thread that gives the eligibility to perform yajna karyas is the yajnopaveeta Yaj jakhyah paramatmaya uchyate chaiva hotrubhih upaveetam tato asedyam tasmadyaj jopaveetikam || Details of yajnopaveeta (the sacred thread) The yajnopaveeta comprises of three threads, and each thread is in turn made up of three fine threads (strands). The three threads that form the yajnopaveeta represent the 3 gunas, 3 vedas, 3 varnas and the 3 lokas. By the order of the Lord the abhimani devatas of these (3 gunas, 3 vedas, 3 varnas and the 3 Lokas) reside in the three threads. tavallokastrayo varnastrivrut sutram samashrayan tat gramthimashrayattarastrimato nadasmyutah tat granthyagram cha savitri vedamata shivajjaya || each of the three threads of the yajnopaveeta in turn is made of 3 fine strands, totally numbering to 9 strands for one yajnopaveeta. the 9 strands (of a single yajnopaveeta having three threads) have the following deities: 1st strand: omkara 2nd strand: agni 3rd strand: bhaga 4th strand: soma 5th strand: pitru 6th strand: prajapati 7th strand: vasu 8th strand: dharma 9th strand: vishvedevatas omkaraprathamastamturdviteeyo agnisthataivacha truteeyo bhagadevatyachaturthah somadevatah pamchamah pitrudevatyah shashthachaiva prajapatih saptamo vasudevatyo dharmashchashtamam evacha navamah sarvadevatyah ityeta nava devatah || the yajnopaveeta should not go either below or above the navel. it has to be changed every year on the upakarma day and also after any ashaucha (mailige). bachelors should wear one yajnopaveeta, where as a minimum of two is compulsory for gruhasthas. the second one represents the extra duty a householder has to perform. (the 2nd one is required since the wife cannot wear a yajnopaveeta and the husband wears one for her, since the husband is the guru of the wife.). gruhasthas can wear even 3 or 4 yajnopavitas, one representing the uttareeya and the other for shreyas. (collections)

Janeewara is the traditional license for gayatri jap, vedic studies and in turn be eligible for rituals. Gayatri jap is not just about reciting, it's about achieving that mantra siddhi. By holding janeewara and reciting gayatri jap, it gets charged with that mantra siddhi (and guards you)

tasmAd yajnAt sarvahutaha richassAmaAni jagnirE chandhAmsi jagnirE tasmAt yajus tasmAd ajAyata Â  Rayaru says: it is from that Being the yajna nAmaka paramAtma who is glorified by all that the Rk, Yajus and Sama Veda and the metres/chandas like gAyatri got revealed from His utterances. Â  The words jagnirE, ajAyata etc mean "born of/born from". Now the Vedas etc are eternal and apaurushEya, in the sense they were not born or created anew and is not authored by a human or dive agency. Hence Rayaru quotes that the Vedas and chandas were revealed by the God through his utterances.Â

919845227048@s.whatsapp.net (919845227048@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 23:52:22
What is the purpose or benefit of wearing tread (Janeewara) and Namas in Gopichandana. ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™
919845227048@s.whatsapp.net (919845227048@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.02 - 23:54:22
Why should we wear yajnopaveeta? Yajnopaveeta is the sacred thread that represents deeksha to perform vedic rituals. Man belonging to the first three Varnas (brahmana, kshatriya and vaishya) has vedadhikara. He can perform sandhyavandana, gayatri japa, agni karya and the like and can also perform vedadhyayana. The pre-requisite to all this is the formal initiation called upanayana where the boyâ€™s father gives the yajnopaveeta and brahmopadesha to his son initiating him into vedic rites. Nobody is entitled to perform any samskara without having gone through the yajnopaveeta samskara according to Manusmruti. One must undergo yajnopaveeta samskara before the vivaha (wedding) samskara. Similarly, shraddha karma is not valid unless the kartru has first undergone the yajnopaveeta samskara. Even when a person does not wear a yajnopaveeta regularly, priests insist upon it during such rituals. The yajnopaveeta is said to have been created by Sri chaturmukha brahma himself for this very purpose: brahmagre kalpayamasa vedarhanamanuttamam yenamse dhrutamatrena brahmasutrena te dvijah bhavanti brAhmana nama vedarhashcha trayastvih || The thread that gives the eligibility to perform yajna karyas is the yajnopaveeta Yaj jakhyah paramatmaya uchyate chaiva hotrubhih upaveetam tato asedyam tasmadyaj jopaveetikam || Details of yajnopaveeta (the sacred thread) The yajnopaveeta comprises of three threads, and each thread is in turn made up of three fine threads (strands). The three threads that form the yajnopaveeta represent the 3 gunas, 3 vedas, 3 varnas and the 3 lokas. By the order of the Lord the abhimani devatas of these (3 gunas, 3 vedas, 3 varnas and the 3 Lokas) reside in the three threads. tavallokastrayo varnastrivrut sutram samashrayan tat gramthimashrayattarastrimato nadasmyutah tat granthyagram cha savitri vedamata shivajjaya || each of the three threads of the yajnopaveeta in turn is made of 3 fine strands, totally numbering to 9 strands for one yajnopaveeta. the 9 strands (of a single yajnopaveeta having three threads) have the following deities: 1st strand: omkara 2nd strand: agni 3rd strand: bhaga 4th strand: soma 5th strand: pitru 6th strand: prajapati 7th strand: vasu 8th strand: dharma 9th strand: vishvedevatas omkaraprathamastamturdviteeyo agnisthataivacha truteeyo bhagadevatyachaturthah somadevatah pamchamah pitrudevatyah shashthachaiva prajapatih saptamo vasudevatyo dharmashchashtamam evacha navamah sarvadevatyah ityeta nava devatah || the yajnopaveeta should not go either below or above the navel. it has to be changed every year on the upakarma day and also after any ashaucha (mailige). bachelors should wear one yajnopaveeta, where as a minimum of two is compulsory for gruhasthas. the second one represents the extra duty a householder has to perform. (the 2nd one is required since the wife cannot wear a yajnopaveeta and the husband wears one for her, since the husband is the guru of the wife.). gruhasthas can wear even 3 or 4 yajnopavitas, one representing the uttareeya and the other for shreyas. (collections)

919483475838@s.whatsapp.net (919483475838@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.03 - 14:16:48
Yajnopaveeta/Jannuve - Part 1 Since the discussion started off with the importance of Jannuve, let us understand the importance of such a yajnopaveeta (YP in short). A part of it has already been posted by Tejas earlier; this is in addition to those points. (These are compiled from the discussions in our FB GSB-M group over the last few years) â€¢ Yajnopavita/ Jannuve (Janivaara) depicts brahmaNatva of a brahmaNa â€¢ Jannuve is an absolute must for study of veda shaastras and its not for the purpose of scratching oneâ€™s back â€¢ Sanyaasis are not required to wear a jannuve â€¢ For us to get the eligibility to practice our daily rituals (nitya karmaanuShTaana) , a jannuve is absolutey essential â€¢ A Brahmin is not supposed to do anything without a yajnopaveeta. â€¢ The 3 threads of yajnopaveeta depict: the 3 Vedas, the 3 deities (Brahma, Vishnu and Maheshwar) and the 3 gunas (satva, rajas and tamo guNas) â€¢ The yajnopaveeta has the presence of: Omkara, Agni, Naga, Chandra, Pitrus (manes), Prajapati, Vayu, Surya, and Vishwedevaatas.
Girish Prabhu (919731211477@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.03 - 14:19:56
ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ğŸ‘

919845227048@s.whatsapp.net (919845227048@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.03 - 14:54:08
While wearing a jannuve (nootana yajnopaveeta dharana), we invite the above 9 devatas in the thread. So a jannuve has the presence of devatas and gives one the power (and hence the yogyata) to perform the various rituals. *Question:* Is a jannuve just an ID card/license? Or is there any direct benefit? *Answer:* As can be seen above, it is not just an ID card to enter, it is also the aadhar card of our life. As our every ritual is dependant on this jannuve. *Question:* Does it give any power just because we wear it? Or is it only to show our brahmanatva? *Answer:* It indeed depicts brahmanatva. But, as can be seen, there is presence of devatas in the jannuve, that give the power to the person wearing it. As devata aavahana is done prior to wearing it, and as the jannuve is submitted to the Lord before wearing it, wearing a jannuve is NOT useless. More questions will be answered in the next part

Manjunath Nayak (917204957396@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.03 - 21:46:27
Please remember.......We are GSBs. We have a culture, usage and tradition of our own dating back to Madhva era. We had Vaishnava leanings even before we accepted Madhva Vaishnava Sidhantha. We have our own way of rituals and we need to follow our respective Math traditions which our elders practised for ages without any problem. We have accepted Madhva Sidhantha but not their acharas and practices. Following strict traditions but with narrow frame of mind doesn't take one anywhere which i have observed by interacting with different Madhwa and non Madhwa brahmin communities. We have comparatively a better and broader outlook towards life with better philosophical leanings. Follow our rich Traditions.... not of any other math tradition just because it is well preached there. We have a beautiful Sandhyavandan system. Let us follow it. We at Bangalore Kashi Math had printed it in 2009_10 under the close guidance of HH Srimad Samyamindra Thirtha Swamiji.

We will have a syllabus. Here is a day wise plan. Every Monday and Thrusday a Topic will be posted by the admins. Monday to Wednesday you have enough time to ask questions *only* on the topic posted on Monday similarly Thursday to Saturday. Questions *only* from Thursdays topic. Sunday will be am open house and any questions related to the previos weeks topic or other paatha relates topics can be asked. But the answers will be given only till Sunday Midnight. We have adopted this system keeping in mind the time constraints for the Admins as well as the students. Everybodys cooperation is expected for a smooth and clutter free functioning of the group. à¤¹à¤°à¤¯à¥‡ à¤¨à¤®à¤ƒ ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™

2017.04.04 - 16:19:32
Here are some fundamental questions of mine, I have heard that Atma can enter any time during the embryo stage or ever at the moment of delivery. *Does each and every organism has Atma? *Is Atma independent of Prana? *Do Lower organisms like Bacteria,Unicellular organisms etc have Atma?If they have *then the Sperms and Ova must have Atma.As they contribute to form an individual how can another Atma enter thereafter? My question may seem ridiculous, but please clear my doubt.
919481588342@s.whatsapp.net (919481588342@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.04 - 16:49:46
*even
919481588342@s.whatsapp.net (919481588342@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.04 - 16:50:52
1. Atma need not contribute to the external form of the organism. A atma which is human by svarupa can take birth as any organism due to prarabda. The svarupa which is intrinsic to atma remains human even in that non human form.
2017.04.04 - 16:56:51
2. Jeevatma enters the womb thru the sperm. There is no half atma corresponding to single helical strand contributed by sperm and egg.
2017.04.04 - 16:58:13
This is detailed in panchagni prakarana. I think it is in Bruhadaranyaka upanishat
2017.04.04 - 16:59:07
3. Only in special cases there is provision for a second soul to enter the same womb. Doesnt happen always
2017.04.04 - 17:00:05
4. Does atma depend on prana? This question is unclear. Which atma whose prana? Mukya prana or the life of the person we normally refer as prana are you referring here?
2017.04.04 - 17:01:38
Life
919481588342@s.whatsapp.net (919481588342@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.04 - 17:07:56
If life is defined as activities of a animal/person's body thru jnaana icha and kriya then that life is just the manifestation of existence of an atma in that body. But that life seen as activities itself is not the atma. Example perhaps given earlier here was Electricity (soul) flowing thru a bulb (bosy) makes it glow (activity). Elsewhere the conducting wire does not glow inspite of the presence of electricity
2017.04.04 - 17:11:44

919483475838@s.whatsapp.net (919483475838@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.04 - 18:11:04
Panchagni prakara is explained in simple words in Hari Kathamrutha Sara : if a soul needs to go back to human form the following things or 5 yajnas takes place where soul goes as ahutiÂ  1. The soul post death will have to bear consequences in heaven and hell as per punya n papa karya it committed on earth once the sufferings or pleasure of naraka or swarga is born the yamadutas take soul to sky in form of gaseous state and they put it as ahuti or offering in clouds this is first yagna where gasous soul becomes cloud 2. The soul in cloud form is put by abhimani devata of sky as ahuti in water and it takes form of water and gets liquid state, the change from gaseous to water form is 2nd yagna 3. The liquid form now waits for rains to flow down and as water drop stays in water and finally falls in earth the transformation from water to mud or soil is 3rd yagna 4. The drop that is soil converts itself as a essential for crop to grown and stays in field as crop till harvest and becomes as paddy or any food item in raw state and post harvest it takes form of lentils or rice particle or tandulu 5. The raw rice now is cooked at home into boiled form and is consumed by male individual in family. Such consumed rice converts as sperm and when the male individual will have inter course with his wife such sperm goes into embryo and grows to full form in 9 months and comes back as infant, the conversion from lentil to infant is yagna number 5
Gopal Pai Man (919886430874@s.whatsapp.net)

ğŸ•‰ à¤¶à¥à¤°à¥€ à¤¹à¤°à¤¿ à¤µà¤¾à¤¯à¥ à¤—à¥à¤°à¥à¤­à¥à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¨à¤®à¤ƒ ğŸ•‰ *Dear Members,* *Here are the revised rules..* *1. Absolutely no posting of photos, videos, sound clips or links unless and otherwise it is an answer to a question raised by the members* *2. Members will be removed after timely warning for non complaince.* *3. Please listen when somebody is answering a question and wait for it to be anwered before asking the next questions. This is to prevent answers getting washed away in discussions* *4. No question is stupid or will be treated as stupid and ridiculing members for the quality of questions will not be tolerated.* *5. A New topic will be posted on every Monday and Thursday* *6. For topic posted on Monday you can discuss and ask questions relevant to that topic till Wednesday and for topic posted on Thursday it can go till Saturday.* *7. Sunday will be open house for any Shastra or GSB spirituality related questions but other days are only for topic based questions.* *8. Criticism of any Matha or Mathadhipati or any argument between members on the subject will not be tolerated by any cost. Members will be immediately removed without any warning in this case.* *9. Any concerns or suggestions should be raised via direct message to the Admins to prevent cluttering of the group.* *10. Always follow the above rules. ğŸ˜ŠğŸ˜ŠğŸ˜ŠğŸ˜Š* *Welcome to the beautiful world of Tatwavada and lotus feet of Hari Vayu Guru.* ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™

919448835656@s.whatsapp.net (919448835656@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 12:23:00
Madhwaâ€™s philosophy in a nutshell The whole gist of Sri Madhwaâ€™s teachings can be summed up to 5 points: 1. Vishnu is the supreme personality of Godhead. (Note: This does not mean that other Gods are to be neglected and discarded.. Infact Acharya repeatedly says that other Gods who are very close to Vishnu are also to be deeply respected which pleases Vishnu) 2. There is difference between Lord(Paramathma i.e Vishnu) and the Living individuals(athma). Lord is infinite and we souls are finite. There is also differences among each souls 3. World is real, and the claims that world is illusion(Mayavada) is not according to the perception nor scriptures. 4. Mukthi or Salvation is the ultimate Goal. It can be achieved only through pure devotion with pure knowledge and according to intrinsic nature of the soul. 5. Perception, inference and verbal evidence are the means for right knowledge Out of these 5 points, our todays discussions will be on the first point i.e Supremacy of Vishnu (Vishnu Sarvottamatva) How can we jump into conclusion that Vishnu is Supreme ? Arenâ€™t there scriptural evidences that prove that Shiva/Shakthi is supreme ? Below is the answer to these valid questions that may popup in our minds. The common perception is that there are many Godâ€™s mentioned in the Vedas, and hence Hinduism is generally called a mixed pot. This is because Vedas also talk of Rudra, Indra etc being superior. But in reality all these are names of Vishnu (Note that in Vishnu Sahasranama the names Rudra, Indra etc addressing Vishnu as Indra, Rudra, Varuna etc. So these are names of Vishnu only come up, but in the strotras venerating Shiva, ). Further, there are many scriptural quotes that indicate that all Vedas speak of one God Vishnu -In the Rigveda, it is declared " à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤¾ à¤à¤• à¤à¤µ"- "He who is the one and only primary bearer of the names of all gods". (X, 82, 3). It is obvious that we don't know who is the "one" referred here. But the same sukta(X,82, 6) answers this question by stating a very specific trait of Vishnu I.e. "à¤…à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤®à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥"- "From His navel springs one". Now, the only thing known to emerge from the navel, in the scriptures is the lotus and that happens from the navel of Vishnu only. Thus we arrive at a conclusion that the 'One' mentioned here as the primary subject of all epithets of all gods is Vishnu only. - à¤‡à¤‚à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¥ à¤†à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯: à¤¸ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤—à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥¤à¤à¤•à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤§à¤¾ à¤µà¤¦à¤‚à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤® à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¤°à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¥: || (I-164-46) "The seers call that One Supreme reality by various names such as Indra, Mitra, Varuna, Agni, the divine bird Garutman, Yama and Matarishwan." -Moreover Kethopanishad says : â€œSarve Veda Yatpadam Amnathiâ€ - All Vedas describe the ONE There are many more scriptural quotes that substantiates this very fact. They will be taken up as we proceed with discussions

Then there was a dispute between Brahma and Vishnu about who is more supreme, at that time, Shiva appeared as Jyotirstambha and asked both of them to reach start and end of it. Vishnu traveled downwards to reach end and Brahma traveled upwards to reach beginning, but both of them failed and considered there is no end of Shiva and asked Shiva to guide them.

2017.04.05 - 20:33:47
Some guidelines at the outset help in achieving the objectives of the group. If you remember Sri Madhvacharya has written kathaa lakshan for exactly this same purpose. It deals with three types of discussions and debates that happen between people. 1) Vaada kathaa 2) Jalpa 3) Vitanda. We in this group should stick with Vaada katha.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 20:44:17
Please explain us it further sir
Rohith Srinivas (918095726821@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 20:47:42

Tejas Kamath (919740584757@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 20:48:13
ğŸ˜³ğŸ¤”
Vidyadhar Sha (919900173230@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 20:50:16
So what is Vaada katha? It is exchange of information that happens purely with the intention of learning. In Jalpa , there are two parties who debate opposing views with the aim of winning a debate . The winner gets a prize or a certificate that he is more knowledgeable etc. So we are not doing Jalpa. Vitanda is just debate. No one discloses the correct information. There is a virtual verbal dual. A fight with words and logical scoring of points till the other party is browbeaten and accepts defeat. In this also there is no aim in learning. So friends, what do we want to do here? Obviously learn something useful. Here there is no need to win and no fight to defeat ğŸ™‚
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 20:51:49
Tejas Kamath (919740584757@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 20:54:22
The Vaada katha happens between Guru-Shishya and like-minded friends coming together to exchange information and advance in their knowledge. So right in the beginning all members should have this mindset.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 20:55:11

Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)

In groups of this type there are many ways the discussion that goes on. One is take up one topic at a time and stick to that topic only. This type of group is rare. Simply because hundred and one types of doubts keep sprouting in the minds of each of over hundred members of the group.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 21:02:16
That leads to the second type of group. Where questions are asked as they arise and answered by anyone else who knows about it. Here we are not in this second type of group. We have created a group *Tattvavada for beginners* All concentrations is to learn the basics one by one and keep climbing the ladder.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)

Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 21:07:43
Type 1 Vishnu maam Vaada Katha
919940286108@s.whatsapp.net (919940286108@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.05 - 21:08:58
Any subject needs to be based on a set of correct sources. So we should first know what are the correct sources of information. Philosophy is a vital field of our life. We have to spend our whole life based on this. So it is not *what I think ..and what another person thinks.* What we believe in should be from those sources which give us *truth* And in the field of unseen entities like punya , paapa, dharma, adharma, Devata, Rakshas etc etc which are the correct sources? They are Vedas (upanishats are part of it) and other texts which are in conformity of Vedas. Which are they? Mula ramayana, mahabharat, pancharatra agamas, and the rest of books which do not violate the principles of the basic texts given earlier. With this I wish our members a good time ahead for useful learning and a best experience

919481588342@s.whatsapp.net (919481588342@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.06 - 22:55:39
A small insight into the way Vedas are to be understood. In the original post we said various names like Indra, mitra,varuna and others are of Vishnu only. Below is the explanation about why? I have tried to be simple. But it can't be oversimplified. So read it at your leisure . I had posted some earlier. I am reposting the same to keep continuity ğŸ‘‡ğŸ»
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.06 - 22:59:11
There are few reasons. One is that paroksha priya hi devah, pratyaksha dvishah. Now Vishnu, though is a direct name let us take the name *indra* When we read it as indra we think of svargadhipati indra , right? But in an upanishat it is said He (parabrahma) is *idandra* which was secretly called indra. This way when we see indra in veda, we think of svargadhipati. But the real indra is Vishnu. Later on I will give another strong reason why ... To continue.. A name denotes some guna. For example *kamala nayana* means one who has beautiful eyes like the petals of a lotus. *Vishnu* means one who is present inside and outside everything. This is given already in the study post by Girishji. So what is *indra*? Indra is one who is rich beyond all imagination. *Mahat aishwaryavan* Of course Purandara , the ruler of svarga is such a one. But we have seen that many a times Shachi pati indra has been conquered by Rakshasas and driven out of svarga. Compare to Vishnu, who is the one with infinite aishwarya, is called bhagavan and at no time and no place has been deprived of His mahat aishwarya. So when Veda says Indra it primarily applies to Vishnu and secondarily (aupacharik) to purandara. This same logic holds to the names agni, varuna, vayu etc etc found in veda
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.06 - 23:00:53
That is why we posted in earlier study post that *sarve vedaah yatpadam amananti...* Of Kathopanishat. Every letter of Veda applies to Vishnu and Vishnu only !
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.06 - 23:05:05
So when we understand this fact, it means complete Vedic literature describes Vishnu's greatness, isn't *Vishnu is supreme* a natural conclusion?
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.06 - 23:07:23
.................à¥ ................... Madhwaâ€™s philosophy in a nutshell The whole gist of Sri Madhwaâ€™s teachings can be summed up to 5 points: 1. Vishnu is the supreme personality of Godhead. (Note: This does not mean that other Gods are to be neglected and discarded.. Infact Acharya repeatedly says that other Gods who are very close to Vishnu are also to be deeply respected which pleases Vishnu) Out of these 5 points, our todays discussions will be on the first point i.e Supremacy of Vishnu (Vishnu Sarvottamatva) How can we jump into conclusion that Vishnu is Supreme ? Arenâ€™t there scriptural evidences that prove that Shiva/Shakthi is supreme ? Below is the answer to these valid questions that may popup in our minds. The common perception is that there are many Godâ€™s mentioned in the Vedas, and hence Hinduism is generally called a mixed pot. This is because Vedas also talk of Rudra, Indra etc being superior. But in reality all these are names of Vishnu (Note that in Vishnu Sahasranama the names Rudra, Indra etc addressing Vishnu as Indra, Rudra, Varuna etc. So these are names of Vishnu only come up, but in the strotras venerating Shiva, ). Further, there are many scriptural quotes that indicate that all Vedas speak of one God Vishnu -In the Rigveda, it is declared " à¤¯à¥‹ à¤¦à¥‡à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤¾à¤‚ à¤¨à¤¾à¤®à¤§à¤¾ à¤à¤• à¤à¤µ"- "He who is the one and only primary bearer of the names of all gods". (X, 82, 3). It is obvious that we don't know who is the "one" referred here. But the same sukta(X,82, 6) answers this question by stating a very specific trait of Vishnu I.e. "à¤…à¤œà¤¸à¥à¤¯ à¤¨à¤¾à¤­à¤¾à¤µà¤§à¥à¤¯à¥‡à¤•à¤®à¤°à¥à¤ªà¤¿à¤¤à¤®à¥"- "From His navel springs one". Now, the only thing known to emerge from the navel, in the scriptures is the lotus and that happens from the navel of Vishnu only. Thus we arrive at a conclusion that the 'One' mentioned here as the primary subject of all epithets of all gods is Vishnu only. - à¤‡à¤‚à¤¦à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤®à¤¿à¤¤à¥à¤°à¤‚ à¤µà¤°à¥à¤£à¤‚ à¤…à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤®à¥ à¤†à¤¹à¥à¤°à¤¥à¥‹ à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¥à¤¯: à¤¸ à¤¸à¥à¤ªà¤°à¥à¤£à¥‹ à¤—à¤°à¥à¤¤à¥à¤®à¤¾à¤¨à¥¤à¤à¤•à¤‚ à¤¸à¤¦à¥à¤µà¤¿à¤ªà¥à¤°à¤¾ à¤¬à¤¹à¥à¤§à¤¾ à¤µà¤¦à¤‚à¤¤à¥à¤¯à¤—à¥à¤¨à¤¿à¤® à¤¯à¤®à¤‚ à¤®à¤¾à¤¤à¤°à¤¿à¤¶à¥à¤µà¤¾à¤¨à¤®à¤¾à¤¹à¥: || (I-164-46) "The seers call that One Supreme reality by various names such as Indra, Mitra, Varuna, Agni, the divine bird Garutman, Yama and Matarishwan." -Moreover Kethopanishad says : â€œSarve Veda3 Yatpadam Amnathiâ€ - All Vedas describe the ONE There are many more scriptural quotes that substantiates this very fact.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 12:24:53
Admins, to start the discussion had given 5 basic points. Yesterday we discussed the most important and basic one *Vishnu is supreme* If there is anything more that members wants to ask/post please do so. Otherwise, with everybody's consent we can move on to the second point *2. There is difference between Lord (Paramathma i.e Vishnu) and the Living individuals (athma). Lord is infinite and we souls are finite. There is also differences among each souls*

Gopal Pai Man (919886430874@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 12:31:42

Gopal Pai Man (919886430874@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 12:32:02
I am posting second part of the Discussion on Vishnu Sarvotamattva.
919940286108@s.whatsapp.net (919940286108@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 12:35:57
8) We know very well, how the pantheon of gods headed by Brahma and Shiva, rushes to Vishnu when there is any threat to the world from an evil force. 9) The Ramayana and the Mahabharata which are the most widely accepted epics, have Vishnu(Rama and Krishna) as their central theme. The Mahabharata is called "Narayana katha" in the Mahabharata itself and also by the famous Kannada poet, Kumara Vyasa in his 'Karnata bharata katha manjari'. The Manu smriti also explains the meaning of the word Narayana in the very beginning, proving He is the primary goal of everything described in it. 10) The births of Brahma and Shiva are very popular in the scriptures. Brahma is said to have born in the lotus from the navel of Vishnu, while Shiva was born from Brahma's anger as described in the Bhagavata. Vishnu is not described as being born from someone in our scriptures. 11) As recorded in the Bhagavata, when there is a specific inquiry as to who is the Supreme among the trinity to whom all the sacrificial oblations are to be offered, Bhrigu rishi visits all the three and gives his verdict that Vishnu is the Supreme among Brahma-Vishnu-Maheshwara. 12) The usage "Harih OM" which is an indispensable part of all Dharmik acts and also an equivalent of 'Hello' in Sanskrit, after all equates Hari(Vishnu) with "OMkaara" and thus brings out the fact that "OM" is the most comprehensive name of Vishnu, which describes His infinite attributes. Clarifications:- Vishnu in His various incarnations might have worshipped Shiva and others. But such acts done by "avataras" like Rama and Krishna is to i) Guide people on earth to do so when particular circumstances arrive, for example Krishna pretended to worship Shiva to get a son, to show the world that those who wish for a son should worship Shiva. After all the very purpose of God coming down in the form of a human is to teach humans. ii) To mislead undeserving asuras, so that they start believing Krishna, Rama etc. aren't the Supreme. iii) Especially when it comes to Rama-Krishna worshipping Shiva, it is clearly mentioned in the Puranas that Shiva had a boon from Vishnu that the latter would worship Shiva in His incarnations. These are a very few logical observations to kindle the fire of conviction in "Hari sarvottamatva". Readers are to open-mindedly go through this and seek more justifications for themselves. The article which succeeds this now, complements whatever is mentioned here and also is a step ahead of this one, in driving home the required point.
919940286108@s.whatsapp.net (919940286108@s.whatsapp.net)

Advaita says that the world is an illusion. All actions and emotions including sorrow are just false impressions. According to dvaita, the world is real. God, the creator of this world, is also real. This is the essence of dvaita siddhanta. The concept of dvaita is relevant even in today's world.

Sanjaykumar Shenoy (918056280552@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 20:48:12
Now let us go back to what was posted in the morning. And see what are the points which prove Vishnu sarvottamattva
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 20:48:13
8) We know very well, how the pantheon of gods headed by Brahma and Shiva, rushes to Vishnu when there is any threat to the world from an evil force. 9) The Ramayana and the Mahabharata which are the most widely accepted epics, have Vishnu(Rama and Krishna) as their central theme. The Mahabharata is called "Narayana katha" in the Mahabharata itself and also by the famous Kannada poet, Kumara Vyasa in his 'Karnata bharata katha manjari'. The Manu smriti also explains the meaning of the word Narayana in the very beginning, proving He is the primary goal of everything described in it. 10) The births of Brahma and Shiva are very popular in the scriptures. Brahma is said to have born in the lotus from the navel of Vishnu, while Shiva was born from Brahma's anger as described in the Bhagavata. Vishnu is not described as being born from someone in our scriptures. 11) As recorded in the Bhagavata, when there is a specific inquiry as to who is the Supreme among the trinity to whom all the sacrificial oblations are to be offered, Bhrigu rishi visits all the three and gives his verdict that Vishnu is the Supreme among Brahma-Vishnu-Maheshwara. 12) The usage "Harih OM" which is an indispensable part of all Dharmik acts and also an equivalent of 'Hello' in Sanskrit, after all equates Hari(Vishnu) with "OMkaara" and thus brings out the fact that "OM" is the most comprehensive name of Vishnu, which describes His infinite attributes. Clarifications:- Vishnu in His various incarnations might have worshipped Shiva and others. But such acts done by "avataras" like Rama and Krishna is to i) Guide people on earth to do so when particular circumstances arrive, for example Krishna pretended to worship Shiva to get a son, to show the world that those who wish for a son should worship Shiva. After all the very purpose of God coming down in the form of a human is to teach humans. ii) To mislead undeserving asuras, so that they start believing Krishna, Rama etc. aren't the Supreme. iii) Especially when it comes to Rama-Krishna worshipping Shiva, it is clearly mentioned in the Puranas that Shiva had a boon from Vishnu that the latter would worship Shiva in His incarnations. These are a very few logical observations to kindle the fire of conviction in "Hari sarvottamatva". Readers are to open-mindedly go through this and seek more justifications for themselves. The article which succeeds this now, complements whatever is mentioned here and also is a step ahead of this one, in driving home the required point.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 20:48:29
Where Shiva says only shri hari is sarvottama
919483475838@s.whatsapp.net (919483475838@s.whatsapp.net)

Prathvish Bhat (919945820316@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 21:21:01
In 2-3 upanishads there is a story about how all gods think they are the main cause for the body to sustain... When each one of them comes out of the body, the body doesn't stop functioning but when Vayu comes out it collapses...not only does it collapse but all gods are 'pulled out' along with him like all bees vacating the hive when the Queen Bee leaves...all gods start glorifying Vayu...you can refer prashna upanishad, talavakara upanishad to completely go through this story
Gururaj Bhandarkar (918892775035@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.07 - 21:21:17
Vishnu Sarvottama - Few questions have been asked which are directly related to the topic and there are few that are not directly related. Few more have been added below, which some people may have in their mind. Let us try to see the questions and the logical answers to those questions: 1) Are all 3 deities Brahma, Vishnu and Maheshwara not equal as they have different responsibilities? Ans: Among the trinity of Gods, both Brahma and Shiva are popularly depicted as in deep meditation, while Vishnu in His moola roopa is depicted as comfortably resting on Shesha. This is obvious as Vishnu doesn't have a superior on whom He is to meditate!! 2) Are all gods not the same? Ans: The river Ganga which emerges from the feet of Vishnu, is devotedly placed on his head by Shiva, while Brahma collects it in his 'kamandal'. We do this when we wash a Swamiji's feet as he is superior to us. Now apply the same reasoning here and decide who is the Supreme! 3) Some say 'Brahman' is the supreme as per upanishads. And Vishnu is just one lower level form of that 'Brahman'. Is this not right? Ans: Make a list of popular Vishnu devotees like Dhruva, Prahlada, Ambarisha etc. and then list out devotees of other gods, like Ravana, Jarasandha, Banasura etc. Compare the two cases, remember the ends they met and this can bring us to the conclusion that Vishnu is the Supreme. 4) There are many stories in puranas that say Shiva is best. There are other stories that say Devi/Shakti gave birth to 3 murtis. Ans: The 'Brahman' of the Upanishads is called so because of His all-pervasion in space, time and attributes(bruhatva). Veda Vyasa on the other hand attributes such all-pervasion to Vishnu by stating "bruhatvAt vishnuruchyatE". The word Vishnu also means the same as Brahman because its root word "vishlr" indicates pervasion('vishlr vyAptow'). 5) Vedas pray only to Indra, Agni, varuna etc (partly addressed in the 1st post). How do we figure out Vishnu is the supreme God? Ans : Another popular term denoting the Supreme God in the Upanishads is 'Atman' who is none other than Vishnu. This is made clear in the Bhagavata where it is said that the three sons of Atri-Anasuya i.e. Datta, Durvasa and Soma manifested from Atma, Isha and Brahma ("dattam durvAsasam sOmam AtmEsha brahma sambhavAhA") . Here, Shiva is called by his popular name 'Isha' and so is 'Brahma'. Vishnu is addressed as Atma which indicates the epithet is very popular for Him in the scriptures. 6) Krishna Himself did puja to Shiva. Rama installed linga at Rameshwara. If Vishnu was supreme, then why did He do this? Ans: When all those crores of gods together were not even able to shake the Mandara parvata to the slightest during Samudra mathana, Vishnu single handedly plucked the mountain, placed it on Garuda, brought it to the ocean and helped the gods churn the ocean. 7) With so many stories, the only way to logically conclude is that the deities are same! Ans : When Lakshmi manifested from the ocean as a result of Samudra mathana, she saw flaws in all gods and divinities present there and chose Vishnu as her husband as He doesn't have any flaws and was the only one there who was so self-sufficient that He never was in need of even Lakshmi while all others out there, both gods and demons yearned for Lakshmi in different ways. This is recorded in the Bhagavata.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)

*manavachana kati dUra nenevara nanusarisi tiruguvanu jAnhavi janaka janaroLagiddu janisuva jagadudaratAnu ghanamahima gAMgEyanuta gA yanava kELuta gaganacharavA hana divoukasaroDane tiruguvanu mane manegaLalli*â€¦ HKAS_02-04 It is not possible to understand completely the Gunas of Creator of Ganges river (ParamAtma), described in the VEda-s and other proclamations. Even His consort LaxmI Devi constantly discovers new Gunas very often. â€œyatO vAcho nivaRtE aprAsya manasA sahaâ€ , says that as much as a distant object is not visible to us, objects far away in the sky cannot be visible at all, similarly the infinite virtuous qualities are not visible to the minds of all. However, the Lord is in the vicinity of the devotees who praise His Lotus Feet constantly. He manifests Himself to them as per their capacity (yogyata) and blesses them. He manifests Himself in the sthula deha at the time of birth itself. In this way He is present with the jiva during Shrishti, Sthiti, laya and in their state of mukti too he reflects Himself with the Jivas and protects them. He keeps the entire world in his belly and protects the Jivas during Pralaya. His greatness is thus supreme. Shri Krishna admired the praises sung by Ganga Putra Bhima while lying of the bed of arrows at the end of the Mahabaratha war and he was blessed by Krishna Similarly the Lord is pleased by the praises sung by His devotees and He resides in the homes of His true devotees along with other Devatas and blesses His devotees by protecting them from the demonic race.

919845227048@s.whatsapp.net (919845227048@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.08 - 22:32:39
Sri Madhwacharya places before you the awesome and majestic form of Vishnu that is given at various places in vedic texts. Remember. We need apaurusheya texts are needed for concluding about anything which is beyond sense perception. By its very nature of being apaurusheya, Vedas are svatah pramana. That means they are true intrinsically. They don't need anything outside from them to prove that they proclaim truth.

Quite a great deeply inquisitive thoughtful set of questions you have raised. ğŸ™‚ Looking at all of the points you have raised I am trying my best to reduce them to much more simple single question. *Discussing about who is supreme, brahma of next Kalpa, need for worship of muktas, indra never becoming brahma and the score of subjects have no use for a common person who is trying get two square meals a day, have a roof over his head, get entertained by the products churned out by bollywood, spend some leisurely time watching his favourite sport, discuss economics and it's effect on society, suggest the best of GST and how it can be improved, effects of policies of American president Trump on the IT companies of India, law and order situations of various indian states, how the recipes used by Hebbar's kitchen found on the net produce the tastiest dishes, why buying the readymade turmeric powder in the market is dangerous due to presence of insecticides etc etc. All these subjects are more relevant to a man's life. And we should study bhagavadgita to find out proper solutions given by Bhagavan Sri Krishna for these subjects. Because we are not doing it here other members are disinterested and do not ask questions.. Is it?ğŸ™‚

2017.04.09 - 09:09:42
[Post 1 of N] Rajesh Kamath Some of the questions you posted have come up in my mind at various points of time in the past. Let me attempt to answer them to the best of my ability, the way I analyzed them. I may be wrong. But at least let me attempt. First let us agree that we all are here to pursue what is truth than who is right. Truth needs to be sliced/diced and dissected in many angles to verify it is indeed truth. In the process of these discussion, if you point out flaws in my thoughts, you will only be helping me to dissect truth in more ways than I already thought of. Going with a brand of truth without really understanding it fully would be like Pierce Brosnan endorsing Pan Bahar Pan Masala without really tasting it or comparing it with others. This might sound like a joke. But there is a serious Catch-22 truth in it - Without really understanding and comparing a philosophy with another, we may never know if it is right. And without knowing what is right ahead of time, one will never read Tattvavada. So it is a cycle. And it can only be attempted to put some thoughts towards that. Here goes some prelude ğŸ‘‡
2017.04.09 - 09:10:40
[Post 2 of N] I hope you agree this is how the world of knowledge operates 1. There are opinions 2. There are informed guesses - And by this I mean you have some facts in hand based on which deduce some other things. 3. And there are facts You are talking of Gita. You are also talking of Krishna. But let me ask a much more mundane question. How do you and I know what Krishna said is correct? You might even have thoughts in mind that Krishna (and Rama) are all human beings elevated to God-hood due to their abundance of good qualities. Or you might think Krishna was a good strategist of winning wars and he is telling us techniques of practically facing life. (Because life is war after all) I might even take a step further and say - Krishna never existed. Mahabharata and hence Gita was the creation of Vyasa - a poet.
2017.04.09 - 09:10:48
[Post 3 of N] So - at this point you do realize that you are voicing a opinion and I am also voicing a opinion. Neither are informed guesses. We might have some facts but we have not connected it till the end and say whatever Krishna said (if he existed) is absolute truth. If he was human, then there might be good chunk of flaws in his Gita. How do I trust this guy Krishna? Could he be playing mind games with his words in so called Gita? After all if you look at Gita from pshycological angle, it is helping a person to develop a certain mindset that gives him the feeling of being happy and preventing from getting depression, disappointment in life. Why should anybody treat a pshycology book with so much reverence?
2017.04.09 - 09:10:55
[Post 4 of N] In any case, my point is: Antecendents of a book, authenticity of a text/person have to be established at the get-go to at least get some conviction that it is truth. Otherwise there will always be lingering doubts and tons of questions and overt or covert disbelief in the mind. Do you agree with this much? Taking this further - you might say the Gita in Channel XYZ is correct. And I might say there is a flower in the sky. Both are opinions. But with your opinion having a greater degree of probablity being correct. Because no one has ever seen a flower in the sky (till now). But both are still opinions nonetheless.
2017.04.09 - 09:11:01
ğŸ™ğŸ™ Narendra maam for ur words. But u know as an admin we all felt if v don giv importance to question other ppl will feel v r intolerant hence answered

919980515970@s.whatsapp.net (919980515970@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 09:21:22
[Post 5 of N] Rajesh Kamath ji We all have 5 sense organs. AN eye sees, An ear hears and so on. There are people who are not blessed with all of them by birth. If a blind person listens to a beautiful song rendering - he might conclude that the singer is very beautiful. How much valid is that conclusion? Ofcourse it is an opinion and might or might not contradict the fact. (We cannot say beauty is a fact because it lies in the eyes of beholder. but i am only saying generally) So it is a forgone conclusion that one sense organ cannnot take the place and make decisions on behalf of that missing organ. Now let me extend this further. Which of the 5 sense organs are allowing you and me to see/hear/smell/touch this God (whoever he is as per you Krishna , Vishnu, Shiva, Alla etc.) SO we are same as that blind person judging the beauty of a singer based on voice. We just are not equipped wth the sense organ to observe the unmanifest God. One might say it is the 6th sense organ viz. mind But mind is also only voicing its opinions. Based on the dozen things we read - our mind formulates an opinion and ays this is God. But at that point it is only the opinion of God of you (your mind). It is no different than my earlier opinion that there is a flower in the sky (which may or may not be correct)
2017.04.09 - 09:23:59
Questions arise when we have half or no knowledge of scriptures or when we are quite advanced in our knowledge and our mind starts challenging or refuses to reconcile conflicting stream of ideas . Let us just post study material and entertain questions only on them...
919980515970@s.whatsapp.net (919980515970@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 09:25:27
Just study (not a casual reading) of what Srikant ji has posted. Those are the lines to be followed for , if anyone is serious to learn. Without such an approach everyone will be going in circles without reaching any worthwhile conclusion. It will getting mesmerized by the oratorical skill of one person today and a second person tomorrow and a third person day after. And all three will be convincing you that all sorts of contradictory views are correct
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 09:25:51
[Post 6 of N] Sure we all have opinions. Whether we acknowledge that or not - we tend to be driven by that first and foremost. It is just an extension of ego (not in a bad way). It is the very existence of us mortals that an I (abhimana) exists. Decreasing it is a noble goal and we all work towards it sometimes badly failing too. So, first let us - both you and I and all others - shun the idea that *MY* opinion is right. We may not explicitly say it. But it will definitely lurking in the mind. (And I can see you mentally nodding your head ) There is no such thing as my or your opinion is right in the realm of unseen, unmanifest. There is also a chasm to cross before accepting Krishna's words in Gita as truth. How to cross that chasm? What is the definitive way of knowing the right thing about unseen God None of my posts are written in response to Rajesh Kamath alone. But it is addressing a general set of questions arising in an open mind before getting conviction. Let me continue next installment sometime later
2017.04.09 - 09:30:31
Kalpa,Bhavi Sameera, Tharathamya etc can be discussed when those topics come up during systematic study. None of us but for a few experts like VISHNU mam etc are qualified to ask questions. None of us are eligible even to ask relevant questions as our knowledge is very limited as ours is non- Sanskrit exposure which is a big handicap in learning vedic knowledge or Acharya Sidhantha s. Let us first learn to unquestions my read what is given to using English by learned guides with welcoming minds. I am sure majority of us have joined to Enjoy the sweet nector of Madhwa whose propositions are considered most advanced . I admire the guides who are patiently handling the situation.

919980515970@s.whatsapp.net (919980515970@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 10:20:31
Part 7 of N I am not answering the question I raised in the previous installments now. Please take some time to think about it Also since Rajesh kamath said Gita being the practical text. and talking about karma, let me briefly delve into it. There is no doubt that Gita is a practival text as everything is. After all one loses count of how many places Krishna mentions Karma Naiva kinchit karoti va, tatah kuru yatatmavan, kurvan siddhim avpsyasi, karma kartu miharhasi, svakarmana tamabhyarchya etc... But most of all the one Rajesh ji cited and arguably the most famous shloka karmanyevadhikaraste ma phaleshu kadachana Give up all desires and do karma - is the literal meaning of this shloka With Krishna speaing of practical karma one would think that Krishna wont talk of impractical things. But alas. How practical is it to give up *ALL* desires to do karma? prayojanam anudishya mandopi na pravartate says a samskrita subhashita. Not even a fool gets into action without any (overt or covert) desire. We work for profit in business. For salary work in offices. If ever there came a rule that all profits to be given to government and all salary earned beyond minimum sustenance amount should be given to government Then everybody will stop working. So much for completely desireless karma. So much for practicality of these words.
2017.04.09 - 10:22:47
Refresh
919980515970@s.whatsapp.net (919980515970@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 10:23:29
[Part 8 of N] Even the much glorified role of mother and father in mainstream literature. A mother feeding her children supposed t have no deisre at all. But reality: Somewhere deep down a desire of the offspring will treat her with dignity and love in her old ages. Is it not a desire? I am inclined to say the complete desireless karma can be done only if you get food from a house where nobody as ever died (Famous Gautam Buddha story) Our mind is a free flowing stream. Flowing in a direction is its natural behavior. Try stopping it. It will turn into a dam for a while. But ultimately it will rebel and explode. Trying to fool ourselves with doing completely desireles karma backfires like the artifical dam going against its very intrinsic characteristic Sanskrit language is like a chewing gum. It can be bent in many ways and still surprisingly be aligned with countless rules of the language. And sanskrit texts use this very liberally. Gita is no different. Our words statements may give conflict meanings. But isnt it true that Krishna had a streamlined thought in his words. then why interpret each statement in isolation? Do you agree with this much? Countless commentators have commented on Gita. They have parroted the literal meaning of this shloka of Gita without any consideration to how human mind operates. Without any consideration to how Krishna would be fool if his different statements meant different things
2017.04.09 - 10:23:57
[Part 10 of N] It s here where Madhva Bhashya shines with the holistic interpretation of the entire text by *also* taking every statement into consideration Madhvacharya says there are two kinds of phala for every karma (with enuf pramana) - Mukhya and amukhya phala. The worldly benefit we desire to some extent is the amukhya phala. However the mukhya phala of every karma is to please the Lord himself (Why please the Lord - More on that sometime later) So when we do karma we should be very aware of working towards giving up the amukhya phala and focusing on mukhya phala i.e. pleasing the Lord. Pshcyologically also this works well. My mind is not getting artificcally blocked into thinking there are no desires. I am channelizing the karma so that there is one God to be pleased. It gives me a different support different angle. Normally if I were typing this to convince you.. there will be some disappointment if you are not convinced. If i say otherwise I will be hypocrite. But I can do this karma with mukhya phala being... you guessed it You might come back and say: Ah so God just a mental dependency (just like you said yajnopavita/gopichandana dharana is a id). But no. More on it later.
2017.04.09 - 10:25:06
So to say in your words Rajeshi ji The *dasha* of a river is to join the sea. we think we can change its *disha* by by building a dam and make it our *vasha*. We only bring more *nasha* because no *paasha* can hold back the disha decided by *isha*. And *shrisha* is the only *isha*. There shouldnt be any *meena-mesha* in accepting this. otherwise there will be *dosha* ğŸ˜ ğŸ™ğŸ™ I will put forth my thoughts later. Please feel free to bring forth your questions

Among 16 samskaras listed which are very much mandatory after birth the 13th or 14th samskara is vivaha which means bonding with a new life time partner and standing as his mistress in all times, in this samskara the girls dad gives his daughter in form of Dana to the able groom, this will ensure the girl moves from one gotra to another and once mangalya is tied by groom to bride she becomes sumangali and soubhagyavati means the girl transformed to woman who brings immense fortune to the family or house she steps in. She gets the right of being a wife, daughter in law and mother in future. Now why mangalya n sindhura, the mangalya u get tied from ur husband is only put after chants of divine hymns and it's not just for show off, the sindhura u put on ur forehead shows u r sumangali and ur presence in anyone's house or function is auspicious and brings lot of good, the ladies who see u in function (atleas some case this is prevalent) call u make u sit on manai and give u vonti symbolising the aura u carry as sumangali. If u believe in samskara u have to believe in the things u need to wear the symbolises it but if u r asking what good will happen as it's just another orbament then shastra has no abswer

919892519191@s.whatsapp.net (919892519191@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 16:46:40
Yes. That is because it is said that there is *ashaucha* sort of uncleanliness or mailige in Kannada
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 16:48:27
At least during Janana and marana one can't see anything unclean physically or for that matter mentally in the family members.
Vishnu Shanbhag (919880241668@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 16:50:28
So the words *shaucha and ashaucha* refer to a condition that is defined only by shastra. This allowance and disallowance is based only on shastra. And we have to accept it as every vidhi (do) and nishedha (don't do) are wished by Lord. Similar is ashaucha in the monthly condition of a woman.

Rohith Srinivas (918095726821@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 18:48:45
@919870725042 [No Gayatri for women - Part 1 of 3] I agree with you that mantra gives many benefits like you listed some. Granted then that both men and women should get all those benefits. God should not be partial (& is not partial) in giving those benefits to both genders. Only the implementation methodology changes. Men are mandated to depend on both Veda Ithihasa and Purana to understand the God. Women are supposed to depend on Ithihasa/Puranas Consequently the vedic mantras are not used by women. The Gayatri mantra being part of Vedic corpus is not used or chante by women. There is a certain tendency of equality saying why cant a lady chant Gayatri etc. And rightfully so. When women feel that they are denied something by what is considered as a male dominant society - there are reasons to be angry. So when it comes to gayatri - when one finally comes to spiritual domain - there too why women are being prevented from chanting by the male dominant society. That is a question that many might get. And the pseudo scientific crowd has not shied away from providing their own interpretations. Like chanting om creates problems for the womb.However much ones like those unproven theories, we just have to set them aside - simply because such outlandish asumptions have no pramana.
2017.04.09 - 18:49:06
ğŸ™ğŸ™ğŸ™
919743026057@s.whatsapp.net (919743026057@s.whatsapp.net)
2017.04.09 - 18:49:08
[No Gayatri for women - Part 2 of 3] So what prevents women from chanting Gayatri? Actually there is nothing preventing women from chanting. Only thing is that nothing will happen at best. Yes nothing will happen ğŸ™‚ (Ignoring the displeasure of Vishnu for the moment) But we do any mantra japa chant so that something should happen right? Something better should happen to us. So why chant something outside adhikara and not get any benefit of chanting other than having a checklist that YES I CHANTED XYZ. If we take a step back and analyze what really is the final goal of our mantra japa chant? Is it stable mind, positive vibes alone or something more than that? The final goal of any japa is Vishnu preetyartha. Even if it is a desire based chant (kaamya), that desire is fulfilled by Vishnu itself. Unless we win HIS PREETI, all chant, any chant is wasteful. If he is pleased everything is in reach. (As the saying goes - Kimalabhyam bhagavati prasanne sriniketane) And if we get the end product (hari preeti), all other intermediate products (stable mind, positive vibes) are obtained automatically Just like a farmer grows paddy - he gets the straw/grass for free along with end product of rice. But farmer's main goal is not growing straw/grass.
2017.04.09 - 18:49:15
[No Gayatri for women - Part 3 of 3] So, I guess we should see what pleases Vishnu? What pleases Vishnu is the chant of something that is based on adhikara. At the very beginning of Brahmasutra Bhashya, Madhvacharya quotes enough pramana and tells about adhikara of Veda is to a certain category of people. When Veda adhikara is given to stree, it is for those in high kaksha like Urvashi, Shachi, Yami etc. In Bhagavata, Krishna says about Shruti smrutir Harerajnaa... Krishna says, the shruti and smruti are orders of Vishnu. One who violates them is not a Vaishnava. I dont like him even if he is my devotee. When our aim through all the chants is to please Vishnu. And when clearly Vishnu says the following a certain adhikara based chanting of things is what pleases him, that probably is the strongest reason for women not chanting any mantra of Vedic origin.But women can and should chant other japa and stotra of not vedic origin.
